msgSnippet: J, If your test class extends TestCase, then the 3.8 rules are applied exactly.  There are still lots of tools that depend fairly strongly on that guarantee.
messageBody:
J,

If your test class extends TestCase, then the 3.8 rules are applied
exactly. There are still lots of tools that depend fairly strongly on
that guarantee. There's not a defined mixing of the JUnit 4.x and
JUnit 3.x rules--the simple things seem to work together, as you
demonstrate, but the more advanced extension mechanisms would make
exactly defining the mix very difficult.

If you want to enforce the JUnit 4 rules, even if the class extends
TestCase, you can annotate your class with @RunWith(JUnit4.class)

1) In your current case, it would require very little effort to
annotate the remaining desired methods with @Test. Is there a real
situation in which it is a significant amount of effort to update a
class all at once?

2) Where did you look in the documentation? Where would be a natural
place to see this behavior described?

Thanks,

David Saff

On Tue, Mar 31, 2009 at 3:40 AM, jduprez4junit <jethrie@...> wrote:
> Hello,
>
> as advised on http://www.junit.org/forum/16, I'm posting to this list
> the following problem - in summary, jUnit4 annotations are ignored by
> jUnit 4 runners when the test class is explicitly extending TestCase.
>
> This case is not uncommon: many users still have jUnit-3.8-style test
> suites and cases, which run unchanged in jUnit4, but may want to enhance
> them gradually, by introducing jUnit4 annotations.
>
> Here is the problem demonstrated as a test class:  the comments mark the
> test methods which behave unexpectedly.
>
> public class TestJUnit4FeaturesBreakIfClassExtendsTestCase extends
> TestCase {
>   @Test
>   public void testMethodWithNameConventionAndTestAnnotation() {
>     // Is executed by jUnit 4, as expected
>   }
>
>   public void testMethodWithNameConventionAlone() {
>     fail("Is executed by jUnit 4 whereas it should be ignored");
>   }
>
>   @Test
>   public void thisIsATestMethodWithTestAnnotationAlone() {
>     // Is not executed by jUnit 4 despite @Test
>   }
>
>   @Test
>   @Ignore
>   public void testMethodWithNameConventionAndTestIgnoreAnnotation() {
>     fail("Is executed by jUnit 4 despite @Ignore");
>   }
> }
>
> Does jUnit intentionally run TestCases subclasses a la 3.8 - to ensure
> backwards compatibility of legacy tests, unchanged?
> It would be a limitation, and indeed makes code such as the extract
> above misleading (as the now familiar annotations do not work as
> expected).
> Besides, I haven't seen this documented in the docs, so I assume it's
> not intentional.
>
> Thanks in advance for following up.
>
>     J.
